posts.name: Gideon Carleton
posts.cooked:
Hello everyone, I have been tuning our swerve drive and i ran into an interesting issue. When i switch from strafing to driving forwards, there is a slight overshoot of the modules, and they do not correct the overshoot until i return the joystick to center. so they end of being about 5 degrees off while I’m driving until i stop. any ideas? here is a link to my repository: GitHub - 6076Mechanica/YAGSL-main

Edit: If there is any need for clearification, I’d be happy to respond. Thanks!

posts.name: Dylan Watson
posts.cooked: Hello! While this may be the result of a number of issues, the simplest sounds like  your turning motors may be stuck in Steady-State error. This is likely solvable by tuning your kF constant to account for this How to tune PIDF | YAGSL . If you want to be sure that it is a PID issue and not an issue with the actual target angle being set, I would recommend using FRC Web Components to track the difference between the target and the current position FRC Web Components | YAGSL

posts.name: jdao
posts.cooked:
This sounds like your angle conversion factor is off.  I ran into this issue last weekend when I was helping a team get a swerve drive up that didn’t have any swerve code, where I initially used the MK4 angle conversion factor instead of the MK4i conversion factor (The swerve drive the team used was a modified MK4i that they uninverted). This resulted in a consistent offset when moving at an angle until we reset the joystick and aimed it at the desired angle again. I think this is a result of the motor correcting off of its internal encoder, but the absolute encoder is able to fix it on subsequent commands.

The calculation of the conversion factor can be found on the YAGSL documentation here . Additionally, common conversion factors can be found in the YAGSL-Configs repo .

link_counts.title: GitHub - BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Configs: Known working YAGSL Configs for COTS swerve modules.

posts.name: Gideon Carleton
posts.cooked: Thanks! i will try these when i get access to the robot next. Another thing that is happening that may be helpful to know is that the robot is not turning in place. The modules rotate, but only minimal power is put to driving, it hardly turns a couple degrees. I am using the example project provided by YAGSL only slightly modified, so I don’t see how this could be happening…

SciborgBotanist6076:

so I don’t see how this could be happening

Every robot is different, the pidfproperties.json file will look wildly different between 2 teams and the values in the example project should be taken as a starting point.

As for why this happens it is likely what has already been stated. What are your module types? I cannot confirm anything in your configs with what you have given.

Your conversion factors are probably wrong then. Did you use the helper functions to calculate them?

I do not have mk2’s documented as a standard conversion factor and the drive gearing is variable.

posts.name: Gideon Carleton
posts.cooked:
So, the constructor of the swerveSubsystem is where the Angle Conversion factor is calculated:

But when the value is printed out later in the program, it is just 12.8, as if the function did not change anything. If I look at the definition of “calculateDegreessPerSteeringRotation()”, i see this:

which calls this function:

Aside from the fact that this doesn’t seem to actually work (The value I get in angleConversionFactor is 12.8), could the problem be that the pulsePerRotation is wrong? we are using an MA3 absolute encoder. I have not found anything in the YAGSL tutorial to indicate that I shouldcchange this. I am going to do the math directly instead of relying on these functions next.

posts.name: Gideon Carleton
posts.cooked: thank you! I will be trying this once I get the robot again!

posts.name: Gideon Carleton
posts.cooked: Awesome! It is working. Now I only have one issue. The robot is moving translationally but it is not rotating. Any idea what could be causing this?

posts.name: Dylan Watson
posts.cooked: What happens when trying to rotate? Does it simply not respond to the input?

posts.name: Gideon Carleton
posts.cooked: When not in motion the modules rotate to the correct direction, but it looks like there is only about 1% power to the wheels. Sorry for the lack of detail right now, I’m a little preoccupied, no issue if I don’t get a quick response

posts.name: Gideon Carleton
posts.cooked: Ok, I have a bit more information. It seems to try to turn in place, but can’t. One possibility is that the IMU needs to be inverted, but i cannot get it to actually invert. whether or not i change the config file, it remains positive-clockwise. maybe i should just flip it physically? I have also disabled headingCorrection, which might have been an issue as well, but i saw no changes.
